entry.title: Top 3 reasons to attend SAP TechEd 2025 in Berlin
entry.content:
After years of digital conferences and small-scale substitutes, SAP TechEd is finally returning to the big stage again!

As someone who literally owes his career to SAP TechEd (more on that later!), I couldn't be more excited about this revival. From my first attendance as a participant to eventually taking the stage as a speaker and ultimately becoming an SAP Mentor, TechEd has been the kickstarter of my professional journey in the SAP ecosystem.

While the virtual editions of TechEd during the pandemic served their purpose, there's something magical about in-person events that even the best-produced, high-definition streaming experience cannot match or replace.

Let me share my top three reasons why you should go for the in-person attendance rather than joining SAP TechEd virtually.

1. Let's re-ignite the community

There's a certain atmosphere to it when thousands of SAP enthusiasts gather under one roof. I still remember my first TechEd as an introvert techie, anxiously navigating through crowds, business card in hand, unsure of whom to talk to. Fast forward a few years, and those initial awkward conversations have transformed into meaningful professional relationships that would shape my career trajectory.

The SAP community is more than just a professional network; for many of us, there's a 'family reunion' flavor to it every time we meet. The spontaneous conversations in hallways, the animated discussions over coffee, and the passionate debates during evening events - these are the moments when we truly connect and 'evil plans' are sketched out. These are the interactions that eventually transform an introverted techie into a more well-rounded IT professional with a global network (anyone else?)

As we emerge from years of virtual-only connections, NOW we have the opportunity to switch back to authentic human interaction. The community needs to reconnect to share common challenges, best practices, and lessons learned.

Don't miss out on this opportunity to be part of this community reunion, and let's re-ignite the community spirit.

2. Embrace Continuous Learning

We live in interesting times, and with a hat-tip to William Gibson, may I say that we all have the privilege to experience the future firsthand?!?

GenAI is fundamentally altering the art of the possible in enterprise software, and by extension, every business function and professional role. At this pivotal moment, staying on the sidelines is not an option for anyone interested in pursuing a career in the SAP ecosystem.

At TechEd Berlin, you'll be able to touch, test, and truly understand the impact of genAI innovations in a way that's impossible through virtual attendance. The hands-on labs, expert-guided sessions, and interactive workshops provide an immersive learning environment that simply can't be replicated online.

Throughout my career in the SAP ecosystem, from working on the founding team behind SAP's cloud platform (now SAP BTP) to my current role focusing on business innovation, I've witnessed how being present at these pivotal technology inflection points provides an invaluable advantage. The questions you can ask in real-time, the nuances you can observe in demonstrations, and the collaborative problem-solving that happens spontaneously - these are the moments when it truly "clicks".

3. Boost Your Career: Grow Your Network, Expand Your Horizon

When I say "I owe my career to SAP TechEd", it's not (just) because I'm a fanboy (OK, I am) or because I drank too much cool-aid; it's true. My professional journey wouldn't have been the same without TechEd. The connections I made and the visibility I gained through presenting technical sessions paved the way to roles I never imagined possible: from becoming an evangelist for SAP Cloud Platform to joining the ranks of the SAP Mentors, it's all connected to TechEd.

Being in Berlin will put you at the pulse of what's happening in the SAP ecosystem. You'll meet the people making decisions about the future of SAP technologies. You'll connect with peers facing similar challenges across industries. You'll encounter potential employers, employees, mentors, and mentees.

A casual conversation might lead to your next career move. A question during a session might identify you as a subject matter expert to someone who needs your skills. Your thoughtful contribution to a discussion might catch the attention of a community leader looking for new voices. The relationships you build and nurture at in-person events like TechEd provide a professional support system that can guide you through career transitions, technical challenges, and professional growth opportunities for years to come.

Make a career-defining choice

While the virtual TechEd experience offers valuable content accessibility, the in-person event delivers something far more profound: a transformative experience that can reshape your career trajectory and professional identity within the SAP ecosystem.

I'm looking forward to Berlin this November, ready to reconnect with old friends and make new ones. I'd love to see as many of you there as possible. Are you in?

If you're ready to go, please register now for SAP TechEd Berlin and tell/bring a friend!

For all those who already booked your trip - I'm curious:

What are your reasons, and what are you most looking forward to? Please share your thoughts!

entry.title: Migration from 0UC_ISU_24 to Recommended Alternatives – Missing Fields Issue
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm currently working on migrating SAP IS-U DataSources to a BW/4HANA environment. The existing system is still running on BW on HANA. SAP provides a whitelist indicating which DataSources are considered obsolete and recommends suitable alternatives for BW/4HANA.

In our case, the DataSource 0UC_ISU_24 is actively used and business-critical. According to SAP’s guidance, the suggested replacements are 0UCCONTRACT_ATTR_2 and 0UCCONTRACTH_ATTR_2. However, we're running into a major issue: the recommended alternatives do not cover all the required fields. A significant number of fields are missing.

This seems to stem from the fact that 0UC_ISU_24 is based on a complex IS-U function module which pulls data from multiple tables, whereas the recommended replacements are far less comprehensive.

So here’s my question:
Has anyone dealt with this migration before and found a working solution?

  • Did you somehow reuse or copy the original extractor logic (e.g., Z-copy of the FM)?

  • Or is there another approach you'd recommend for getting all the necessary data into BW/4HANA?

Any experience, suggestion or direction would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance

entry.title: How SAP’s AI Agent Architecture Enables Unprecedented Automation and Decision Augmentation
entry.content:
AI agents are redefining business applications. Enabled by advanced reasoning capabilities, they plan, act, reflect, and collaborate to perform tasks and make decisions based on data and predefined business objectives. These agents have the potential to automate business processes and act as assistants for human users, reimagining how work is structured, how decisions are made, and how value is created. Here you can find out more about AI Agent use cases and the value they provide.

Looking back at SAP Sapphire on May 20-21, 2025, we are at the forefront of agents with the launch of an expanded network of Joule Agents, the AI agent hub in SAP LeanIX and the announcement of the agent builder capability in Joule Studio.

This blog post is the first of a series that dives deeper into various aspects of SAP’s AI agent offerings and their technical underpinnings and architecture.

SAP’s AI Agent Strategy

At SAP we run the most mission critical business processes end-to-end through the broadest application portfolio in the industry. With more than 75% of the world's transaction revenue touching an SAP software system, SAP is uniquely positioned to embed AI agents into business processes to drive value. We view AI agents as an integral part of our strategy, seamlessly integrating them across all our cloud applications and BTP.  SAP Business Data Cloud preserves the business context and semantics of your business data, providing the foundation for these agents. This powerful cycle – connecting applications, data, and agents – unlocks unprecedented value for our customers. 

We are committed to designing relevant, reliable and responsible AI agents centered around the human user, automating or supporting them in their daily tasks and decision-making. So, how do we make this a reality? 

SAP’s Architecture for AI Agents 

Businesses must move beyond traditional software systems toward AI-native solutions, where business logic, user interfaces, data access, and governance are inherently designed for agentic collaboration. At SAP, we are fundamentally evolving our approach to business applications as we tackle this once-in-a-generation opportunity. Rather than encoding domain expertise and best practices into pre-defined workflows, we now ground the future of AI agents in that very expertise, enabling more dynamic, adaptive, and intelligent systems. 

SAP specializes in business agents. Our teams are developing a wide range of pre-built SAP agent use cases centered around high-impact areas such as customer experience, supply chain management, spend management, finance, and human capital management. These agents are relevant since they are embedded in your business applications and processes right from the start.

SAP introduced Joule as the omnipresent conversational entry point for AI, enabling simple and efficient human and agent interactions across all our applications and your browser. We are shifting from traditional user interfaces – separate dashboards for analytics, enterprise search, and business processes – toward a unified, AI-driven experience that seamlessly integrates them all. What sets Joule apart is that it is agentic by design, capable of reasoning, planning, and orchestrating actions across multiple agents to solve even the most complex tasks. Beyond conversational triggers, we empower agents to be activated by business events, workflows, or applications to maximize the potential of AI agent automation.

Acknowledging our diverse customer landscapes, rather than imposing a one-size-fits-all solution, we provide our customers the flexibility to extend and configure SAP-built agents in Joule Studio. This enables you to fine-tune our agents to your processes or adapt them to work with third-party solutions. To meet customers’ needs for a business agent development platform, your developers can build your own agents via Joule Studio or agent SDKs to tap into previously unrealized potential. 

To power your custom low-code no-code agents as well as SAP-built Joule Agents, we offer a managed agent runtime as part of SAP AI Foundation. This runtime features deeply researched agent flows and reasoning capabilities, along with a seamless integration into your SAP and non-SAP software systems right out of the box. For this, we leverage a combination of reason and act, plan and solve, and custom steps for grounding, reflection and consecutive learning.

We view both structured and unstructured data as key strategic assets for AI, equipping our agents with a comprehensive suite of data access tools. However, data alone is not enough, AI also needs access to the underlying semantics and relationships. SAP Business Data Cloud preserves your business context and semantics of all your mission-critical SAP and third-party data with an open data ecosystem. Together with knowledge retrieval and grounding capabilities – powered by resources such as SAP Knowledge Graph and document grounding – this makes our agents inherently reliable, as they are rooted in your company’s information, policies, and files. From day one, these agents can explore and deeply understand your business systems, processes, and domain data, bolstered by SAP’s extensive industry and process expertise. Through our partnership with Perplexity, our agents can even conduct in-depth research across external data sources to enhance your business decisions.

Our agents utilize Joule functions as integration tools to interact with their environment and business systems. Joule functions address essential concerns like security and connectivity centrally, ensuring smooth connectivity of our agents to your business systems. Furthermore, reusable agent tools, including web search and code execution, enhance agent capabilities.

As enterprises deploy numerous AI agents, orchestration and collaboration among those agents become critical. To enable use cases spanning multiple vendors and domains, our agent and tool registry along with support for agent interoperability protocols (e.g. MCP, A2A), allow customers and partners to incorporate their own tools or agents from external vendors, fostering an open agent ecosystem and marketplace.

Responsibility is at the core of our AI agent design, adhering to SAP’s stringent AI privacy and security standards. Every action taken by agents on behalf of users is audit-logged and personal data is filtered, while industry-leading identity and access management with dedicated agent identities and authorizations ensures secure automation without compromise.

We recognize that despite the utility of AI agents, humans remain integral to business decision-making and reasoning. Therefore, we deliberately design our AI agents following our AI ethics policy and to keep humans in the loop to review and approve work done or proposed by AI agents. Thanks to advanced explainability techniques, users can trace and fully understand each AI-driven decision or action, allowing for intervention or guidance whenever necessary. Through robust monitoring and governance services, alongside AI agent hub in SAP LeanIX, we ensure humans remain in control.

Conclusion

By seamlessly integrating pre-built Joule Agents into our business processes, applications, and SAP BTP, we are dedicated to unlocking unprecedented value for our customers. We empower our customers to create custom agents and enable extensibility of SAP agents through Joule Studio. By enabling interoperability, we cultivate a vibrant agent ecosystem ready to adapt and grow. Our strategy is centered around building trust, ensuring control, and enhancing business readiness – key components for maximizing the transformative potential of AI agents.

Looking ahead, we are committed to staying ahead of the rapidly evolving AI landscape, continually exploring and innovating in this exciting field. In the upcoming six months, we plan to further refine our platform for agents and expand our coverage of high value use cases. To fully tap into the potential of automation, we're concentrating on the next generation of AI agents: system-triggered agents that proactively create solutions before issues even become apparent. By forging strong partnerships with Google, Mistral, NVIDIA and Perplexity, our agents will be well-equipped for the future.

Join us on a journey to explore the technical foundations that empower our business agents and stay tuned for the next parts of this series covering: 

  • Unifying AI Workloads with SAP HANA Cloud: One Database for All Your Data Models
  • Reasoning and Planning in Joule: the Omnipresent Orchestrator for Agents and AI
  • AI Tooling and Data Foundation with SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Knowledge Graph
  • Building content-based AI Agents with Joule Studio or code-based Agents with AI Foundation
  • Enterprise-grade Security and Access Control for AI Agents
  • Agent Interoperability and Ecosystem with A2A and MCP

Co-authored by Dr. Jan Dumke and Alex Schaefer

entry.title: API Consumption - S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition and S/4 HANA Cloud,Private Edition
entry.content:
With the evolving SAP landscape and customers moving to S/4 HANA Cloud , our prime focus as a consultant is to follow a clean core approach.

SAP Business Accelerator Hub(https://api.sap.com/) is one such platform which helps us in discovering standard APIs,Events, Extensibility options

which we can consume in our S/4 HANA landscape to achieve end-to-end business functionality. This blog focusses mainly on the API consumption from

SAP Business Accelerator HUB and how it differs between the two of the S/4 HANA Cloud offerings - S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition and S/4 HANA Cloud,Private Edition.

We will first go through some of the basic differences and then focus on technically how we can use or consume these APIs in each of the environments.

 

S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition

S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition

Where to find?

 

Ready to use APIs available in Business Accelerator Hub(https://api.sap.com/) to be explored under the Tile -

 

Ready to use APIs available in Business Accelerator Hub(https://api.sap.com/) to be explored under the Tile –

 

Activation

 

Communication management based API Activation. APIs are part of a standard communication scenario. Communication scenario can be found from SAP Business Accelerator HUB as below –

 

 

SICF based API activation(OData V2)For OData V4 no specific activation is needed but the Service Group needs to be published. Not associated to any communication scenario.

 

 

Sandbox availability

“TryOut” option available in SAP Business Accelerator HUB for OData APIs to execute the CRUD methods with Sandbox data. Also you can deploy your own system to do tryout with your actual data of your S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition system.

 

 

 

No Tryout option available with any Sandbox. Also here the S/4 HANA system is in a private network and often there will be a Cloud Connector in between so TryOut options have been restricted for APIs for Private Edition

 

 


 

 

 

Consumption

API is consumed through a communication arrangement which is based on a standard communication scenario. Standard Fiori Application -   Communication Arrangements to be used for consumption.

For OData V2 API is activated through transaction code - /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE.

For OData V4 API no separates activation is required but service group needs to be published through transaction code - /n/IWFND/V4_ADMIN

Practice Guide

We will be using OData V2 - API - API_PRODUCT_SRV as an example to demonstrate the activation of the API in S/4 HANA Public Cloud and S/4 HANA Private Cloud.

API Link for Public Edition – https://api.sap.com/api/API_PRODUCT_SRV/overview

API Link for Private Edition - https://api.sap.com/api/OP_API_PRODUCT_SRV_0001/overview

 

Scenario 1# Activating API in Public Cloud –

Navigate to the link https://api.sap.com/api/CE_PRODUCT_0002/overview  for the API or you can search the API as below.

In https://api.sap.com/ go to the tile SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

Under APIs go to ODATA V2 and search with “Product” and open the one Product Master(A2X) which say ODATA V2 API and is “Active”  for usage.

 

From SAP Business Accelerator HUB you will get the SAP standard communication scenario for the API –

 

Here we will be creating arrangement for communication scenario – SAP_COM_009

Next create a communication user from the Fiori application “Create Communication User”.

 

Give a Username and you can use the “Propose Password” option or you can add your own password.

 

Next step is to create a communication system from the Fiori application “Communication Systems”

 

Click on “New” and provide a System ID and System Name –

 

 

Go to tab “Users for Inbound Communication” and assign the user you just created in the previous step using “Create Communication Users”.

 

 

For the ease of use you can check the checkbox “Inbound Only” which means you are not expecting any outbound communication (S/4HANA -> External) through this communication system and so you will not be asked to enter any user for Outbound communication user for this communication system.

Save the communication system.

Next step is to create the communication arrangement. Go to application “Communication Arrangements”

 

Click on “New”

In the following tab enter “SAP_COM_0009” as the standard communication scenario for API_PRODUCT_SRV.

 

Select the ‘Communication System'(from value help) which we have just created in the previous step. The assigned Communication User will now automatically appear in User Name field.

 

Click “Save” and it will activate your communication arrangement.

You can get your actual service URL for all Inbound Services associated, under the tab “Inbound Services” under the column “Service URL/Service Interface”.

Similarly all the Outbound services associated with this communication Scenario “SAP_COM_0009” will show under the tab “Outbound Services”.Outbound services are generally either SOAP Outbound services or IDOCs.

 

 

All the services that belong to the communication scenario “SAP_COM_0009” will be listed here under the tab “Inbound Service”.

Get the URL where the Service says “Product Master(A2X)” / OData V2”

 

The API link looks like this - https://<host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PRODUCT_SRV

So this makes your API ready for consumption from the external system.

Get the service URL and test it from POSTMAN using the communication user that you created in the first step. In POSTMAN you can use it for Basic Authentication under Authorization.

You can call this URL from SAP Integration Suite using a OData V2 Adapter with basic authentication with the user you created in “Communication User” application.

Note – For Public cloud the way of activating a OData V2 service and OData V4 service are same unlike Private Cloud where there is a difference.

So for OData V4 the API will be also activated by a communication arrangement only as shown above and the URL will look like this - https://<host>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_product/srvd_a2x/sap/product/0002/

Link to API Hub for the OData V4 API of Product Master - https://api.sap.com/api/CE_PRODUCT_0002/overview

 

Scenario 2# Activating API in Private Cloud –

First step same as Public cloud to find the API from https://api.sap.com/ .

Navigate to the link https://api.sap.com/api/OP_API_PRODUCT_SRV_0001/overview for the API or you can search the API as below.

In https://api.sap.com/ go to the tile SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition

 

Under APIs go to ODATA V2 and search with “Product master” and open the one Product Master(A2X) which say ODATA V2 API.

 

 

Next Run Transaction Code - /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE

Click on “Add Service”

Provide System Alias = “LOCAL” and under Technical Service name – “API_PRODUCT_SRV” and click on “Get Services”

 

Then select the service you want to activate and click on “Add Selected Services”

You can provide the package where you want to assign the service.

 

If you want to use OAuth authentication you have to check the checkbox “Enable OAuth for Service”

The next step is to activate the service as shown below. However it is recommended to go and activate the service from SICF transaction code.

 

Your OData V2 Activation is complete and you can test it from the Gateway. You can call this service now from SAP Integration Suite with a technical user who has the necessary roles.

 

 

Bonus Scenario # Now we will see how we can activate a similar OData V4 service of Product Master.

To find the OData V4 API go to https://api.sap.com/ and go to the node – “SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition”

:291522iD133E2FCB72EF160:

 

Under APIs->ODATA V4 -> Search Product

 

Select the “Odata V4” one which is “Active” and not “DEPRECATED”

 

Under API Resources -> Attributes you will find the Service Group Name which you need to publish.

 

Now Go to Transaction - /n/IWFND/V4_ADMIN and click on “Publish Service Groups”

 

Next enter the Service Group Name you got from Business accelerator Hub and click on “Get Service Groups”

 

 

Now your OData V4 API will be ready for consumption from Integration Suite.

entry.title: Re: Use of statistical projects
entry.content:
I look at statistical projects in these terms.  In SAP FICO is FI (Financial Accounting) and CO (Managerial Accounting).  Managerial Accounting is internal control of the business.  When you post a P&L cost in SAP is must be assigned to a single "real" cost object (WBS, IO, Cost Center, etc.) for correct FI postings.  But management might also want to see these costs in a different perspective.  Simultaneously you can post costs to a second cost object as long as it is Statistical.

Example of a Statistical WBS Element Use in SAP:

Imagine a company that is undertaking a large construction project with multiple phases, such as planning, development, and execution. The project manager wants to monitor the performance and productivity of each team working on the project, such as the design team, engineering team, and construction crew.

Instead of creating a WBS element for each team that impacts the financial aspects of the project, the project manager can set up statistical WBS elements for each team.

I can't seem to find any APIs for this functionality. Could you please suggest any idea to achieve this by standard or through custom development?

Thank you.

Kind Regards,

Praneetha

entry.title: Change labels of the hard coded gender values in German languages
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We have a business requirement to adjust the German labels of the Gender List. The standard delivered values are currently:

  • M – Männlich
  • F – Weiblich
  • U – Unbekannt
  • D – Nicht deklariert
  • O – Sonstige

Due to legal requirements, we need the label ‘Divers’ to replace ‘Nicht deklariert’. Since the gender values appear to be hardcoded, could you please advise on how we can change the German labels accordingly?

Thank you!

Kind regards,
Erika

entry.title: Enabling Joule Studio in SAP Build for existing Joule customers
entry.content:
Introduction

This post is intended for existing Joule customers who are looking to enable Joule Studio and start building custom Joule skills.

If you're enabling Joule for the first time—for example, with SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, or SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud—and want to activate Joule Studio alongside, we recommend starting with the Discovery Center mission: Establish a Unified Joule Instance. You should also check out the helpful blog series by my colleague @Diganta_Mandal, starting with Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio.

On the other hand, if you’ve already enabled Joule with any of the SAP cloud solutions mentioned above and have an active Formation of type Integration with Joule (you can verify this in your BTP Global Account under System Landscape > Formations), then this blog will guide you through the steps to activate Joule Studio within your existing setup.


Motivation

We often receive questions from existing customers about how to enable Joule Studio. Some of the most common ones include:

  • Do we need to run the Joule booster again to enable Joule Studio in SAP Build?
  • Does SAP Build Process Automation need to be in the same subaccount as the Joule instance?

You’ll find answers to these and other key questions as you continue reading this blog post.

Prerequisites Before You Begin

  • Make sure your global account has the SAP Build entitlement, specifically the plan: build-default (Application).
  • Confirm that your SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant is included in your existing Formation.
  • Next, subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation with the plan: build-default (Application) in any subaccount of your choice. For guidance, refer to the Provisioning Setup section in Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio. Note: You can skip the Joule Booster step in this case.

Important: Joule Studio is not compatible with tenants using the SAP Build Process Automation (plan: standard). A new subscription using the build-default plan is required.

If your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant is not already part of your Formation and doesn't appear under System Landscape > Systems in your global account, you will need to manually add it.

Steps below for adding  SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant in your system landscape.

  1. Navigate to System Landscape > Systems and switch to the Service Owner View.









  2. Click on Add System and enter the details of your Cloud Identity Services tenant.


Steps to add SAP Build Process Automation in existing formation

  1. Go to your existing Formation of type Integration with Joule.

  2. Click Include Systems to launch the system inclusion wizard.
    Note: Your formation may already include systems like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Public/Private Cloud, or other supported solutions.

    Answer to Question 1 (from the Motivation section):
    If Joule is already running with other solutions, you do not need to run the Joule Booster again to enable Joule Studio.


  3. In this example, a new subaccount named Joule Studio was created specifically for this purpose, with SAP Build Process Automation (plan: build-default) enabled in it.

    Answer to Question 2 (from the Motivation section):
    SAP Build Process Automation does not need to be in the same subaccount as the Joule instance.

  4. Select the Joule Studio subaccount and click Next Step.



  5. Choose Enable Capability Deployment, then proceed with Next Step.

  6. Review the summary and click Include.



    Your formation will begin synchronizing.



After a short while, if all steps have been completed successfully, the formation status will change to Ready.

You’re now set to start using Joule Studio to build and deploy your own custom Joule skills.



To continue, follow the next steps in the blog to:

  • Assign roles for Joule Skills developers. Refer Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio.
  • Begin skill development using this blog post: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 2: Developing and Deploying a Joule Skill

entry.title: Webcast Series: SAP's Four-Part Journey Through Architecting Modern SAP Landscapes
entry.content:
In an era where digital transformation has evolved from competitive advantage to survival imperative, enterprise architects find themselves at the crossroads of unprecedented technological convergence. The traditional boundaries between artificial intelligence, cloud platforms, and business applications are dissolving, creating both immense opportunities and complex architectural challenges. To address this shifting landscape, SAP’s global Enterprise Architecture & Advisory team recently delivered a four-part webcast series that charts a course through the most pressing architectural questions facing organizations today.

This series, "Enterprise Architecture for Modern SAP Landscapes," was developed at the invitation of the broader "Move to Cloud ERP" webcast series, powered by the SAP Global User Groups Organization to serve the worldwide SAP community."

It represents more than just technical guidance—it's a strategic roadmap for navigating the fundamental transformation of how businesses architect, deploy, and govern their technology ecosystems. From debunking persistent myths that paralyze decision-making to realizing the promise of clean core principles, each session builds upon the others to create a holistic view of modern enterprise architecture, delivering the practical insights that user groups across the globe have been requesting for their digital transformation journeys.

 

Part 1: Debunking Enterprise Architecture Myths

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Date: June 10, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Enterprise Architect, SAP

The series opens with perhaps the most critical challenge facing enterprise architects today: separating fact from fiction in SAP’s modern architecture paradigms. The opening session, “Debunking Enterprise Architecture Myths: Clean Core, SAP S/4HANA, and BTP,” tackles seven persistent misconceptions that continue to derail digital transformation initiatives across organizations.

These aren’t merely technical misunderstandings—they’re strategic barriers that cost organizations millions in project delays and suboptimal architectural decisions. The session demonstrates how clean core principles extend far beyond SAP S/4HANA implementation, enabling strategic custom development while maintaining upgrade safety and innovation velocity. Through architectural patterns and real-world case studies, attendees learn to counter myths with evidence-based approaches that accelerate rather than impede transformation.

What makes this session particularly valuable is its focus on communication and stakeholder management. Enterprise architects often find themselves in the unenviable position of defending architectural decisions against deeply held misconceptions. This presentation equips them with the truths and techniques needed to lead evidence-based discussions in executive steering committees.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

 

Part 2: Architecting Innovation-Platform Ecosystems

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Date: June 17, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Enterprise Architect, SAP

The second installment shifts focus to one of the most significant architectural transformations of our time: the evolution from traditional product-platform ecosystems to dynamic innovation-platform ecosystems. “Enterprise Architecture for Transitioning from Product-platform to Innovation-platform Ecosystems” explores how enterprise architects can design the foundational layers necessary for fostering co-creation and external innovation.

This session is grounded in rigorous academic research by @Michael_Blaschke, drawing from his peer-reviewed studies on platform ecosystem dynamics and digital transformation patterns. The presentation unveils the architectural building blocks required to create open, scalable innovation-platform ecosystems that support API-first strategies and platform economics while maintaining essential governance and security controls.

The transition from product-platform to innovation-platform ecosystems represents a fundamental shift in how organizations create and capture value. Enterprise architects learn to design the organizational capabilities that enable ecosystem participation, support multi-sided marketplace dynamics, and unlock network effects—all while ensuring the organization doesn’t sacrifice operational stability for innovation velocity.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

Supporting Research:

  • Dynamic capabilities for transitioning from product platform ecosystem to innovation platform ecosystem
  • Capabilities for Digital Platform Survival: Insights from a Business-to-Business Digital Platform

 

Part 3: AI-First and Suite-First Convergence

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Date: June 24, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Enterprise Architect, SAP

The third session addresses perhaps the most complex architectural challenge of our time: orchestrating the convergence of AI-first capabilities with suite-first principles. “Enterprise Architecture Convergence: AI-First and Suite-First Strategy for Modern Digital Landscapes” explores how enterprise architects must evolve their frameworks to architect truly future-ready organizations.

This presentation goes beyond the typical AI integration discussion to examine the deeper architectural patterns required for pervasive AI adoption. The session demonstrates how to harmonize three critical elements: AI integration with Joule as the intelligent copilot, unified business data cloud capabilities for cross-portfolio insights, and consistent suite qualities that ensure security and performance at scale.

The convergence theme is particularly relevant as organizations struggle to integrate AI capabilities without fragmenting their existing architectural coherence. Dr. Blaschke provides practical guidance on designing landscapes that embrace AI-first thinking while maintaining the governance and integration integrity essential for enterprise-scale deployments.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

 

Part 4: Enterprise Architecture View on Clean Core

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Date: July 1, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Principal Enterprise Architect, SAP

The series concludes with “Realizing Clean Core using Cloud Extensibility: An Enterprise Architecture Perspective,” which provides the practical implementation guidance necessary to transform architectural vision into operational reality. This session reveals how enterprise architects can maintain pristine core systems while enabling seamless cloud-based extensions.

The clean core principle represents one of SAP’s most significant architectural innovations, but its implementation requires careful balance between standardization and customization. The presentation demonstrates how to establish architectural guardrails that prevent core pollution, leverage cloud-native extension patterns, and create flexible composition layers that enable innovation without compromising stability.

This final session ties together themes from the entire series, showing how clean core principles enable the platform ecosystem transformations discussed earlier while providing the architectural foundation necessary for AI-first initiatives. The result is a comprehensive approach to enterprise architecture that balances the sometimes competing demands of standardization, innovation, and agility.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

 

The Global Enterprise Architecture & Advisory Impact

These sessions represent the expertise and experience of SAP’s global Enterprise Architecture & Advisory team, part of the Premium Engagement & Advisory practice. This specialized team serves as strategic business partners to regional enterprise architect teams, helping customers drive digital transformation initiatives across the globe. Their focus on board-mandated and critical customer situations positions them uniquely to understand and address the most complex architectural challenges facing modern organizations.

The team provides dedicated enterprise architecture expertise to enterprise-grade customers, partnering with senior executives to architect modern enterprises. This hands-on experience with strategic transformations informs every aspect of the webcast series, ensuring that the content reflects real-world implementation challenges and proven solution patterns.

 

Charting Your Architectural Journey

Together, these four sessions provide enterprise architects with a comprehensive framework for navigating the complexities of modern digital transformation. They address not just the technical aspects of architecture but the strategic, organizational, and governance challenges that determine transformation success.

The series acknowledges that modern enterprise architecture requires more than technical expertise—it demands the ability to lead organizational change, communicate complex technical concepts to business stakeholders, and design solutions that balance competing priorities across multiple stakeholder groups.

For the SAP Community's global audience of customers, partners, and practitioners, this webcast series offers both immediate practical value and strategic vision for the future of enterprise architecture. Whether you’re debunking myths in steering committee meetings, designing innovation-platform ecosystems, orchestrating AI-first transformations, or implementing clean core principles, these sessions provide the frameworks and insights necessary to succeed.

The journey toward modern enterprise architecture is neither simple nor straightforward, but with the right guidance and frameworks, organizations can navigate this transformation successfully. This webcast series represents a valuable resource for anyone committed to architecting modern enterprises.

Special thanks to Larissa Brinkmann and Krenar Kuqi for their excellent collaboration, and to the SAP Global User Groups Organization for providing this platform to showcase SAP’s thought leadership in enterprise architecture.

This series, "Enterprise Architecture for Modern SAP Landscapes," was developed at the invitation of the broader "Move to Cloud ERP" webcast series, powered by the SAP Global User Groups Organization to serve the worldwide SAP community."

by Dr. Michael R. Blaschke

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition - F0798 "Create Bil...
entry.content:
Hello @ravi_kumar100 

The F0798 Create Billing Documents app does not currently offer a dedicated role or authorisation restriction to control or lock the Billing Settings section within the app UI.

The Billing Settings (layout, defaults) are stored locally per user and are considered personalisation settings, not configuration or master data. These cannot be restricted via business catalogues or authorisation objects.

Currently, there is no standard functionality to restrict users from modifying these settings.

Create Billing Documents-SAP HELP

Best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Build process automation RDP mode and limitations on mouse click in virtual environments
entry.content:
Hi,

I would like to know how to find out mouse click limitations that can never be done even when RDP is configured. We have virtual environment where bots are running during lots of SAP Gui, excel or outlook automations without any issues. Once there was a scenario with two excel subsequent pop-ups where buttons needed to be clicked (click sync) that worked only when user was connected looking at the session - probably these pop ups were not recognized when user disconnected. After configuring RDP based on this - to be honest not quite intuitive documentation: (https://help.sap.com/docs/intelligent-robotic-process-automation/desktop-agent-user-guide/manage-unlock-with-desktop-agent?locale=en-US) it started to work even without user connected to session. Therefore I assume RDP has been set up correctly.

Now we have UI5 automation that needs to perform Mouse Click. And this mouse click is never performed when user is disconnected. Therefore I am looking for some simple way how to either doublecheck RDP configuration or how to find out exact situation when mouse clicks are not possible in virtual desktops. As this only says "certain circumstances":

 

So I would like to know what are these "certain circumstances" as when customer asks for some use case, basically we dont know whether its gonna work in VM or not until whole scenario is finished. Only at the end we find out that some elements do not react on click but only to mouse click. Also when using application recorder, all the buttons are recorded as click and later we find out they only react on mouse click.

Many thanks to product experts @cherry_li, @Chaitanya_Priya for any advice.

entry.title: Re: custom field creation for work center maintenance pla...
entry.content:
Hi Habeeb

As I understand, the current situation is you have a created a Custom Field (type Date) for Asset Maintenance: Maintenance Order, you have also enabled it as a filter for the Manage Work Center Utilization app, which is a tile access able from the Resource Scheduling for Maintenance Planners app. Of course, because this field is empty, it returns no data - it is not associated with the Created Date for the maintenance order for example.

So at the moment you have an empty maintenance order custom field that you want to populate so you can use it for the filter.

The Manage Work Center Utilization app is not enabled for extensibility according to the Fiori App library.

However, according to the help, these are your options: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/8014207c0ba144cc8ad58f31a6f6a8e6.html?locale=en-US

Essentially, you can adapt filters and add fields to the table with the table settings.

Unfortunately, the 2 views that you have enabled are not released (check the View Browser), so you can't work with them.

My initial idea was maybe you can create a Custom Business Object and associate the date field there with the main maintenance order. If you could do this, you can expose the CBO as a new app and edit the field there. You can check these views to see if any are suitable for this purpose (under the API tab)

However, if you could do that, introducing another app just to edit the custom field seems excessive.

You can investigate the above mentioned apis in the screenshot and check if you can do anything with Developer Extensibility or a Side by Side scenario where you update the custom field via an API.

Finally, can you use the existing Time Period field and just set it to the date of the Maintenance Order? 

If you are wanting to influence the date range of the tile in Resource Scheduling for Maintenance Planners, I unfortunately don't see a way to do that.

You may want to investigate Manage KPIs and Reports or a custom business object on one of the CDS Views in the above API screenshot to create a custom report to meet the requirement.

It would be good to revisit the original business requirement to see if there is another app or report that could be leveraged

Please let me know your thoughts

Thank you

Jerry

entry.title: Chart Enhancements in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
With the 2025 Q3 QRC release of SAP Analytics Cloud, we’re excited to introduce a series of enhancements to our Charts that are designed to provide more flexibility and control in the Optimized Experience. These updates are aimed at improving the visual appeal and the analytical precision of your dashboards, helping you tell a clearer story with your data.

Within this Blog Post, we will highlight the key enhancements which include:

  1. New Design for Numeric Point Chart
  2. Grid Lines 
  3. Axis Titles
  4. Axis Line Thickness
  5. Grouped Category Divider Line Color and Thickness

You can find an example of how these improvements can visually enhance your existing dashboard

 

New Design for Numeric Point Chart

The Numeric Point Chart has been redesigned to better align with modern dashboard aesthetics and to improve readability. With the fresh look, we ensure key figures stand out more prominently, making it easier for users to quickly grasp performance metrics.

Given that the Numeric Point Chart is significantly different, we have decided that it must be enabled on a per Chart basis which is non-reversible. For new Charts, it is automatically made available.

 

Grid Lines

We’ve introduced Grid Lines which can be toggled on and off via the Designer in the Charts Show / Hide settings. It can help improve the readability of the Chart and make it easier to interpret data points that have their data labels hidden due to collision. There is an option to update the color of the Grid Lines via the Styling Panel.

 

Axis Titles

For Viewers to have better context, Designers can now add Axis Titles which reflects the name of the bound object. It helps in understanding what data is being represented on each axis.

For the Axis Title, we allow the configure of the color and position. For the X-Axis Title we support a left, center, and right alignment while for the Y-Axis we support a centre and top alignment.

 

Axis Line Thickness

The thickness of axis lines can now be adjusted between Thin, Medium, and Thick via the Styling Panel under Axis Line. It can be used to suit your design preferences or to emphasize specific aspects of a chart.

 

Grouped Category Divider Line Color and Thickness

Designers now can customize the color and thickness of divider lines between grouped dimensions. This improvement enhances the clarity of grouped data and helps in distinguishing between different segments more effectively.

 

Within the Blog Post, we also wanted to highlight a few improvements that were shipped in previous releases that could be beneficial. The key enhancements include:

  1. Adjust Bar Width at Widget Level
  2. Improved Data Label Position for "Line" based Charts
  3. Sort with 100% Stacked Bar Charts

 

Adjust Bar Width at Widget Level

You can now adjust the bar width at the widget level, instead of having to use Chart Scaling, giving designers greater control over the appearance of individual bar and column charts.

Setting the widget-level bar width overrides chart scaling bar width and default bar width settings for the chart. All other chart scaling settings are still applied.

 

Improved Data Label Position for “Line” based Charts

We’ve improved the positioning of data labels for line-based charts to enhance readability. Labels are now placed more intelligently based on the chart layout and available space.

 

 

Sort with 100% Stacked Bar Charts

We now support sorting for 100% stacked bar charts, allowing users to order categories based on values or measures. This enhancement improves data analysis by making trends and comparisons easier to interpret.

 

These enhancements are part of our continued effort to empower users with precise, customizable, and visually engaging tools in SAP Analytics Cloud. Stay tuned for more updates as we evolve the platform to meet your analytical needs.

entry.title: How to Build Stock Validation Skills in Joule Studio
entry.content:
Build Maintenance Validation Skills Using Joule Studio  in SAP Build (Part 1)

Intro: Empowering Maintenance Operations with Joule Skills

Joule Studio enables business users and developers to build Joule Skills that automate backend tasks and simplify decision-making. In this hands-on guide — the first of a two-part series —We’ll walk through creating a set of Joule Skills that help retrieve maintenance orders, fetch material and component details, and check stock availability, forming the foundation for intelligent decision-making, using a CAP-based service on SAP BTP.

We’ll focus specifically on how to design, build, and test Joule Skills inside Joule Studio. The backend logic used to check maintenance order status and stock availability is already deployed as a reusable service on SAP BTP and exposed through a destination.  

Use Case: Intelligent Maintenance Stock Validation 

Maintenance planners often face delays when required components for maintenance orders are unavailable. The validation process today is manual and error prone. 

With Joule Studio, we can automate this. Our Joule Skills we’ll build will: 

  • Retrieve pending maintenance orders 
  • Identify components required 
  • Check material stock availability 
  • Return the result to the user or agent consuming the skill

 

Now that we've outlined the business challenge and solution approach, let's dive into the hands-on implementation. We'll build this step-by-step, starting with the foundational setup and progressing through skill creation.

Prerequisites

Before we begin building our maintenance validation skills, you'll need access to Joule Studio. If you don't have Joule Studio set up yet, please follow the comprehensive setup guide available at: How to Get Started with Joule Studio

This guide will walk you through:

  • Accessing Joule Studio in your SAP BTP environment
  • Setting up the necessary entitlements and subscriptions
  • Configuring your development environment
  • Understanding the basic Joule Studio interface

Our Development Approach:

  1. First, we'll establish the connection to our backend service.
  2. Then, we'll create individual skills for each business function.
  3. Finally, we'll test and deploy our skills for use.

Step 1: Configure the Destination in SAP Build Lobby 

To connect Joule Studio to the backend service, you’ll first configure a destination directly in the SAP Build Control Tower. 

This destination will point to an already deployed CAP service that exposes the necessary maintenance order and stock validation logic. 

Create a New Destination 

  1. Navigate to the SAP Build Lobby .
  2. Go to Control Tower > Destinations.
  3. Click “Open in BTP Cockpit”.
  4. In the BTP Cockpit, Navigate to:
    • Connectivity > Destinations

 

5. Click Create Destination and fill in the following configuration: 

  • Name: sample-maintenance-service 
  • Type: HTTP 
  • Description: Maintenance Order Service
  • URL: https://sample-maintenance-srv-i760021.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/maintenance-order 
  • Proxy Type: Internet 
  • Authentication: BasicAuthentication 
  • User: TECHNICAL_USER 
  • Password: TECHNICAL_PASS

 

 

 

6.  Click Check Connection to verify the destination. You should see a green checkmark if the connection is successful.

Step 2: Create an Environment in SAP Build 

Before adding destinations or creating skills in Joule Studio, you need to create an environment in SAP Build. This environment acts as the runtime space where your agents and skills will be deployed and executed. 

To create an environment: 

  1. Open the SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Environments 
  3. Click Create Environment 
  4. Enter a name for your environment, e.g., Joule studio demo 
  5. (Optional) Add a description if needed 
  6. Click Create 

Later, you’ll associate your destination and actions with this environment to make them usable in your skills and agents 

Step 3: Add the Destination to SAP Build  

Now that your destination is created in BTP, as we did in Step 1, we need to make it available inside SAP Build to use it in Joule Studio. 

  1. Open SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Destinations 
  3. Click Add 
  4. In the wizard: Select your destination (e.g. sample-maintenance-service) 
  5. Click Next 
  6. Associate an Environment 
    1. Select the environment you created in Step 2(e.g., Joule_studio_demo) 
    2. You can choose to make the destination available in all environments or only the specific environment which you created in step 2 .
  7. Click Add Destination 

Once added, this destination will now be available to associate with environments and to use in Joule skills. 

Step 4: Add an Action in SAP Build (Expose Your API) 

Now that your destination is available and associated with an environment, the next step is to create an Action that defines how your backend API should be called by Joule skills. 

Actions are the bridge between destinations (backend APIs) and Joule Skills. 

You can upload an open API specification or build an action from scratch using the destination you added. 

Option 1: Upload OpenAPI Spec from Your Project 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Upload API Specification 
  3. Note:The API spec is provided as a .txt file containing JSON content in the attachment.
    Before uploading, rename the file to have a .json extension  so Joule Studio correctly detects the format.
  4. Upload your openapi.json file. 
  5. Click Next to continue 
  6. You’ll now be prompted to Create an Action Project. 
  7. Fill in Project Name and Description according to your use case.
    • For example, you can name the project Maintenance Fulfillment Agent API , since these APIs will later be used by a Joule Agent (covered in Part 2 of this series). 
  8. After creating the action project, you will see a list of all endpoints from your uploaded specification (you can select maximum up to 20) 
    • Select all the 6 endpoints needed for your use case. 
    • Click Add to include them in the project. 

8. Once the action is created, go to the Test tab and select the destination you created. Since the maintenance order API lists all orders, no input is required by default. If you'd like to filter by status (e.g., pending, open), you can add that later as an input parameter. Click Test to verify that the API returns a valid response. 

 

9. You should see 200: OK response from the API. 

Once tested, you can release the project to create a version of it. 

 

 10.Once released, click Publish to make the version available for Joule Skill creation 

Note: Releasing and publishing the action is required. Unpublished actions won’t appear when building a Joule Skill. 

Option 2: Alternatively: Build the Action from Scratch 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Build from Scratch 
  3. Fill in the required fields: 
    • Operation: GET 
    • Name: Enter a name for your action (e.g., CheckMaintenanceStock) 
    • Description: Enter a brief description (e.g., Checks stock for components in a maintenance order) 
    • Endpoint: eg., /MaintenanceOrder) 
  4. Define any request parameters and expected response fields. 
  5. Click Release and Publish the action just like in the previous method for the actions to be available. 

For our use case, we will be using Option 1. 

Step 5: Create a Project and Joule Skills 

Now that the destination is configured, the environment is created, and your action has been added and published, you’re ready to build a custom Joule Skill that calls the required API from your service. 

These skills will be reusable and can later be connected to an intelligent agent in Part 2 of this series.

Create a New Skill Project 

  1. Open Joule Studio in SAP Build. 
  2. Click on create > Create Skill  
  3. Enter 
    • Project Name: eg., Intelligent Maintenance Order Stock Validation Agent   
    • Description: e.g., Skills to validate whether maintenance orders can be fulfilled based on stock availability
  4. Note: While we’re only creating Joule Skills in this post, we’ll use the same project to add and configure the Joule Agent in Part 2 of this series.
  5. Click Review > Create 

Once the project is created, you’ll be taken to the Overview tab, where you’ll see the project name and description. 

 

 

The project will be created after you click “Create”.  

Add a New Joule Skill 

  1. In the project, click Create 
  2. From the dropdown, select Joule Skill.
  3. Fill in: 
    • Name: e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 
    • Identifier: e.g., get-maintenance-order 
    • Description: e.g., get list of a maintenance order  
    • Click Create 

 

 

Add the Parameters to the Skill 

  1. Open the skill by clicking its name or the arrow icon to the left .This is the panel where you need to add input, output parameters.  
  2. In the “General” tab, update the name/description of the Joule skill. 
  3. Keep the toggle “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” ON (so the skill can be started directly by the user, not just via an agent).

     

  4. Go to the Parameters tab. Click Configure to add input and output parameters. 
  5. Inputs allow Joule to collect user input in the conversation interface. 
  6. Outputs define what information will be shown to the user after the skill executes. Add the input parameter: 

➕Add Input 

  1. Add the following Input: 
    • Name: User query 
    • Description: Context for the endpoint to give the list of the orders 
    • Required: Unchecked 
    • Click Apply to save the input. 

➕Add Output 

  1. Add the following Output: 
    • Name: List of Orders 
    • Type: Any 
    • List: Checked 
    • Required: Checked 
    • Description: List of orders depending on the user request (e.g., pending or open orders) 
  2. Click Apply to save the output. 
  3. Output types can vary — choose the appropriate type based on the structure of your API response. 
  4. You’ve now configured both input and output parameters for your Joule skill. 

Add an Action Step to the Skill 

  1. Click the ➕Plus icon to add a step
    1.  
  2. Select Call Action 
  3. In the Action search: 
    • Either browse all actions 
    • Or use the search bar to quickly find your previously published action (e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails) 
    • Click Add 

 

 

 

Configure the Action Step 

  1. After adding the action, you’ll see General, Input, and Output tabs. 
  2. In the General tab: 
    • Set Step Name: Get maintenance orders 
    • For Destination Variable, create or select one (e.g., Fulfillment_agent) 
    • Click Create to add the destination, then select it. 
  3. Go to the Input tab and map the input (e.g., user query). 
  4. In the Output tab, you can view the API’s response schema. 
  5. Click End to configure the skill’s outputs and map the expected output value. 
  6. Click Save to finish the step configuration. 

 

 

Create Skills for Each API Endpoint 

We have already created a skill which uses GET/MaintenanceOrder  

 

Tool Name 

Endpoint 

Description 

GetMaintenanceOrders 

GET /MaintenanceOrder 

Retrieve all maintenance orders (can be filtered) 

GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}') 

Get details of a specific maintenance order 

cGetOrderOperations 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}')/operation 

List operations under a maintenance order 

GetOperationComponents 

GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

List components for a specific operation 

GetMaterialDetails 

GET /Material('{ID}') 

Get material details 

GetMaterialStockLevels 

GET /Material('{ID}')/stockLevel 

Check stock availability for a material 

 

For each skill, remember to: 

  • Configure input and output parameters.
  • Set the correct destination variable.
  • Turn on “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” if creating Joule Skills.

Tip: Use the Action Definition to Configure Skill Parameters 

When configuring the Skill Input and Skill Output, you don’t need to guess what the API expects or returns. 

You can find this information directly from the Action definition you uploaded earlier: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions.
  2. Open the Action project you created .
  3. Select the relevant endpoint.
  4. Navigate to the Input and Output tabs 

From there, you can: 

  • See which input parameters are required 
  • Understand the expected output structure and data types 

 

 

 

 

Example: For GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

  • Input: ID of the operation (marked with a red asterisk = required) .
  • Output: 
    • value → A list of components (type: list) 
    • count → Number of items (type: number) 

Use this information to accurately define the parameters in your Joule Skill > Parameters tab. 

  

Step 6: Release and Deploy Joule Skills 

With your Joule Skills created and configured, the next step is to release and deploy them to your environment so they can be used in real scenarios.

  1. Click Release to version your Project.

  

       2. Go to Project > Versions 

       3. Click Deploy 

 

 

During deployment: 

  1. Select the Environment created in Step 2 (e.g., Joule Studio demo) 
  2. Select the Destination you added in Step 3 
    • You will only see destinations that are: 
      • Associated with this environment 
      • Or made available to All Environments 
  3. Click Deploy 
  4. After deployment, the agent status will appear as Active 

 

 

 

Test the Skills in Joule Studio

To interact with your the skills: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Environments 
  2. Click your environment (e.g., joule studio demo) 
  3. Under your agent project, click More > Joule 
  4. Click Launch to open the Joule Chat window 

You can now start chatting with your agent using real-world prompts. 

 

For example: 


Debugging Agents Flow 

  • You can open the Debug Panel in the top right corner to see details of how Joule selects the skills based on the user input.  

Example Prompts to Test the Joule skills

  1. “Show me all current maintenance orders” 
  2. “Get details for maintenance order 25” 
  3. “What operations are planned for maintenance order 4?” 
  4. “What is the description of material 19” 
  5. “How many units of material M-45678 are in stock?” 

Wrapping Up Part 1: Skills First, Intelligence Next

In this first part of our Joule Studio blog series, we focused on building the foundation: creating, configuring, and deploying individual Joule Skills that interact with maintenance orders and material data. These skills are now live, testable, and ready to be reused across various automation and intelligence layers.

Each skill is designed to handle a focused task — whether it’s fetching order details, retrieving stock levels, or listing required components. With these deployed, you're now ready to take the next leap: combining them into an intelligent agent.

In Part 2, we’ll build a Joule Agent that brings your deployed skills together into an intelligent assistant — one that can understand maintenance-related questions, check if orders can be fulfilled, identify what’s blocking them, and even suggest solutions such as replenishment needs or follow-up actions.


Part 2 will show you how to build an intelligent maintenance agent that brings your skills to life — stay tuned!

If you're interested in diving deeper into Joule Studio and expanding your knowledge beyond this use case, here are valuable resources to accelerate your learning:

Learning Resources

  • Learning Journey - Comprehensive guided learning path for Joule Studio
  • Documentation - Official technical documentation and reference guides
  • Discovery Center Mission - Hands-on missions to build practical skills
  • Joule Studio Tutorials - Step-by-step development tutorials
  • Architecture Overview - Technical architecture and integration patterns
  • Smart Advisory Companion – Inspiration Video - See Joule Studio in action with real-world scenarios

These resources will help you explore additional use cases, advanced features, and best practices for building intelligent automation solutions with Joule Studio.

entry.title: Sustainability Control Tower: Update on SAP-provided Metrics on ESRS regulation (continued)
entry.content:
This is a continuation of Sustainability Control Tower: Update on SAP-provid... - SAP Community

Co-author @elsandoval 

Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of the SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) as of July 25th,  2025. 

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) supports customers on ESG reporting. Therefore, SCT enhances the coverage of metrics provided which are in line with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS). 

This blog-post provides an overview of metrics which are planned or newly released and gets updated regularly. Please note that the names of planned metrics may be subject to change. For the full list of available metrics in SCT, please visit Metrics | SAP Help Portal 

Released Metrics (as of July 25th 2025)
In some cases metrics are marked as "(documentation only)". That means those datapoints are not part of the scope of standard metrics delivered by SAP and therefore documentation is provided in the help portal. This is the case if e.g. for quantitative metrics a customer specific breakdown is requested or for qualitative metrics, in case datapoints are already covered in other datapoints. 

Qualitative

Sustainability MatterMetric NameDisclosure RequirementData Point
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINAre All Value Chain Workers in Scope of Material IROs S2.SBM-3(11)(AR 6-AR 7)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINTypes of Value Chain Workers Subject to Material ImpactsS2.SBM-3(11a)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAIN(Documentation only)
Type of value chain workers subject to material impacts by own operations or through value chain
S2.SBM-3(11ai-v)

Undertaking has supplier code of conduct		S2-1(18) (2)

entry.title: Re: SAP Business Data Cloud - FAQs
entry.content:
@SreekanthSurampally 

Customers can also create their  own data products using data from any SAP or non-SAP application. These are called customer-managed data products and are created and managed in SAP Datasphere.

The data and its related ORD file are stored in the customer’s storage area within SAP Datasphere (Embedded Object Store). Both customer-managed and standard data products work the same way — they are stored in an object store, described by an ORD file, and published in the SAP BDC Catalog.

entry.title: Re: Local RAP business event consumption in S/4HANA 2023 OP
entry.content:
If the events are not in a released API, then you can make a request to SAP via Customer Influence platform for new feature and hope that they put this on their roadmap.

Following page explains that business event can be consumed locally: Business Event Consumption | SAP Help Portal
I pasted the steps from there.

Creating an Event Handler Class

1. Create a class that will serve as the event handler class. For the introductory syntax of the global class, use the keyword FOR EVENTS OF, followed by the name of the behavior definition that contains the event to be consumed.

 
CLASS cl_local_event_consumption DEFINITION
						PUBLIC
						ABSTRACT
						FINAL
						FOR EVENTS OF root_entity.
 

2. In the definition section of the local class contained in the Local Types, include cl_abap_behavior_event_handler as superclass to inherit from.

 
CLASS lcl_local_event_consumption DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_event_handler.
 

3. Define a method for each event to be handled. In the method signature, specify the importing parameter, the entity, as well as the event to be consumed.

 
PRIVATE SECTION.
              METHODS consume_event_1 FOR ENTITY EVENT importing_parameter_1 FOR my_entity~event_1.
              METHODS consume_event_2 FOR ENTITY EVENT importing_parameter_2 FOR my_entity~event_2.
            ...ENDCLASS.

            CLASS lcl_local_event_consumption IMPLEMENTATION.
            METHOD consume_event_1.
              CHECK importing_parameter_1 IS NOT INITIAL.
            ... ENDMETHOD.

            METHOD consume_event_2.
              CHECK importing_parameter_2 IS NOT INITIAL.
            ... ENDMETHOD.
            ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Enhancing Your SAP Support Experience – Sunset of Ask an Expert Peer
entry.content:
Your support experience matter! – and we are evolving with purpose to meet your changing needs and provide you with the best support experience. As technology advances and business demands grow, we continuously refine our support strategy to deliver faster, smarter, and more personalized assistance. As of July 1, 2025, we simplified our support channels by retiring the Real-Time Support live channel “Ask an Expert Peer” in SAP for Me. This change is the beginning of a more agile and connected support experience.

What Changed?

To better align with your needs, we’ve officially retired the Ask an Expert Peer option in SAP for Me. You may notice that the familiar button has been removed from the ‘Best Action’ recommender in the ‘Get Support’ application.

Why the Change?

By sharpening our focus on proven support live channels, we’re enhancing your ability to get answers when you need them. SAP is committed to delivering a consistent, intelligent, and outcome-driven support experience. After careful evaluation and customer feedback, we are consolidating our efforts into scalable and intelligent Real-Time Support channels that offer broader coverage and tighter integration into SAP's support and product ecosystem.

  • Faster Resolutions: By focusing on the most effective channels, you’ll get answers and solutions quicker than ever.
  • Consistent Expertise: Enhanced live channels provides you access to the best expertise.

We encourage you to take full advantage of SAP’s Real-Time Support portfolio, designed to give you faster answers, expert guidance, and AI-powered insights when and where you need them.

What Does It Mean for You?

  • In SAP for Me, you’ll now be seamlessly guided to our highest-performing live support channels like Case, Expert Chat, Schedule a Manager and Schedule an Expert.
  • If you previously relied on Ask an Expert Peer, transitioning to these optimized channels will feel intuitive and efficient.

💡Good to know: Want to keep content from your previous Ask an Expert Peer sessions? You can export your history via the ‘Case List’ application.

Note:
Ask an Expert Peer will continue to be available in the Ariba Help Center. You can find more information in this SAP Knowledge Base article: 2998816 - Ask an Expert Peer - Frequently Asked Questions - SAP Technical Support

Your SAP Support Team
